Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Development of a TCAD Framework for Nanowire Solar Cells

POR.DRECONTENT:
Unfortunately, there are no outcomes yet to list for this project. TCAD model development has proceeded within our group at the University of Washington, with the current focus being on oxygen precipitation, metal gettering, and BO2 complex models for silicon solar cell applications. While pursuing CIGS research does not fit into our current project schedule, it may be a topic we return to, perhaps with additional collaborators. 

The chief problem encountered during the course of this project was difficulty obtaining measurements of impurities within a CIGS system. There are many open questions concerning the structure of CIGS-based PN junctions. We attempted to investigate common CIGS structures using ab initio calculations but these proved to be intractable given the size required to simulate CIGS systems with material interfaces and fabricated stoichiometric ratios.

Sodium is often included in small concentrations in CIGS systems, diffused from a soda-lime glass substrate, because it has been demonstrated to improve device performance. Accordingly, a possible area of focus would have been continuum model development for sodium diffusion in a multicrystalline CIGS system using two-stream diffusion models that can account for diffusion along grain boundaries. This necessitated measurements of sodium transport in CIGS that, owing to the low concentrations and the detection limits of available equipment, could not be reliably carried out.
